courses.description: (UGEB1217 is double-coded with BMEG1217.)  This course exposes students to a range of state-of-the-arts developments in biomedical engineering. It invites students from various disciplines to discuss the long-term societal impacts and ethical implications of these technological advances, particularly in human enhancements beyond therapy. The course starts by illustrating the many amazing designs in our human body and yet how vulnerable we are in terms of injuries, diseases and ageing. Examples on how modern biomedical engineering helps us face our human conditions are given, such as musculoskeletal prosthetics and orthotics, cardiovascular implants, neuroengineering, stem cells and regenerative medicine, gene editing, bionanotechnology, intelligence and artificial intelligence and senses and artificial senses, etc. A historical account of human quest for “living” machine, including a brief coverage of modern movies on bionic human then follows. The course wraps up with some social, ethical and philosophical reflections on the above issues and on the meaning of being human, opening up questions concerning the perennial human quest of becoming super human.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the subject, students will be able to:

1. Describe some of the amazing designs in human body & their potential damages due to injuries, diseases, & ageing;
2. Give examples on how engineering has helped in reconstructing damaged body parts and/or body functions, such as musculoskeletal prosthetics, cardiovascular implants, artificial sight, tissue & genetic engineering, etc.;
3. Reflect on our human imagination about the bionic human of the future; and
4. Discuss some of the philosophical, societal and ethical issues associated with such technological development.

Higher-Order Learning and Literacy: Students will be given sets of thematic reading assignments (listed as common reading requirements in the Reading List and Reference section), and asked to question, discuss, and illustrate their readings using some instructor-prepared worksheets as guides. Throughout the subject, students will be drawn to reflect on their views on the distinct characteristics of being human. Each student is expected to critically review one of the selected books (given in the Reading List, total reading not less than 200 pages) in a book report (~2,500 words).

Life-Long Learning: In this interdisciplinary subject, students will be constantly facilitated and drilled to learn across their disciplines. We regard such an interdisciplinary learning capacity an important skill for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Human life is both amazing and vulnerable. Amazing – the designs and working of our human bodies are the envies of engineering science. Vulnerable – the best and the strongest are still mortal. We are susceptible to trauma, diseases, ageing and finally death. Advances in life science and engineering are bringing to us in fast cadence and big strides innovative breakthroughs and new possibilities in healing and rejuvenation, functional recoveries and health enablement. Powered intelligent prostheses for subjects with amputation, fully implantable artificial hearts for subjects with heart failures, tissue engineered skin for severely burnt subjects, stem cells therapies for impaired brain tissues are examples that our body can be fixed by replacing the defective components with artificial “spare parts” and other augmentative measures. At the same time, research laboratories are developing intelligent robots that can see, hear, smell, talk, walk, dance, think, and feel like human – following a centuries-long human quest for “living” machines. The mechanistic implications of these biomedical and engineering advances seem apparent – Is human a robot? Can robot one day become human? The artists among us are quick to perceive and even exploit these implications. The entertainment media have imaginatively presented many kinds of human-robotic hybrids, both as heroes and villains, often with power and abilities beyond those of a human. What could we tell about ourselves from our quests, pursuits, and dreams? How may one define the borderline between human and robot? What does it mean to be a human?

* *\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*SELECTED TOPICS FOR PRO & CON PAPER****\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\***
(Student can select one of the following topics for critical review.)

1. Humans should seek self-enhancements with the help of bioengineering technologies.
2. Humans should use genetic engineering to endow their off-springs with the best opportunities for success.
3. Amputees should be allowed to use prosthetics to compete in regular Olympics.

courses.description: This course covers the definition, scope, basic principles and problems in biomedical engineering, introduction to the enabling technologies for biomedical engineering. It provides the overview of various topics in biomedical engineering, e.g., biomedical sensors, bioinstrumentation, bio-signal processing, biomechanics, biomaterials, molecular engineering, tissue engineering, bio-nanotechnology, medical imaging and rehabilitation engineering, etc. It covers the applications of engineering principles to selected medical and biological problems and contemporary roles and challenges of biomedical engineering.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken BMEG1130 or BMEG2000 or BMEG2130 or ESTR2200 or ESTR2201.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to
- Have a general picture of the overall curriculum of the biomedical engineering undergraduate programme, especially on the choice of advanced electives; and
- Explain and illustrate how important functions of the human body are studied using principles of engineering and quantitative methods; and
- Apply basic principles of science and engineering to study living functions and to understand the operation of biomedical instruments.
courses.course_syllabus: This course covers the definition, scope, basic principles and problems in biomedical engineering, introduction to the enabling technologies for biomedical engineering. It provides the overview of various topics in biomedical engineering, e.g., biomedical sensors, bioinstrumentation, bio-signal processing, biomechanics, biomaterials, molecular engineering, tissue engineering, bio-nanotechnology, medical imaging and rehabilitation engineering, etc. It covers the applications of engineering principles to selected medical and biological problems and contemporary roles and challenges of biomedical engineering.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Feedback from students is collected via the following channels:

1. Short essay assignments
Students will write up their views on a different biomedical engineering topic every week. They will also indicate certain points that they do not understand well from the lectures. Teaching assistants will follow up with the students accordingly.

2. Informal online contact
Students can show their comments via email. Teaching assistants will follow up with the comments or pass the information to the course instructor if necessary.

3. Individual consulting
Students can make appointments with the course instructor and teaching assistants to exchange opinions for improving the quality of course.

4. Faculty course questionnaire

A midterm evaluation will also be conducted. At the end of the course, students are required to fill in the questionnaire to provide feedback on different aspects, including comments on the teaching and learning of the course.
courses.required_readings: Relevant reading list will be provided by course teachers.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. John D. Enderle, Susan M. Blanchard, Joseph D. Bronzino (Ed.). Introduction to biomedical engineering. Elsevier Academic Press, 3rd edition, c2011. (ISBN: 978-0123749796)

2. S. N. Sarbadhikari. A short introduction to biomedical engineering. CRC Press, 2007. (ISBN: 978-1420060119)

3. Michael M. Domach. Introduction to biomedical engineering. Pearson/Prentice Hall, c2004. (ISBN: 978-0136020035)

4. John G., Webster. Medical instrumentation: application and design. John Wiley & Sons, c2008. (ISBN: 978-0471676003)

5. Selected research papers

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Biomedical Engineering Laboratory and Hospital Experience
courses.description: This course provides hands-on experience in various aspects of biomedical engineering, introduction to basic electronics, chemistry, molecular biology, microbiology, electrophysiology laboratory techniques and hospital visits. Laboratory skills, experimental design, interpretation of data, technical writing and safety and ethical issues relevant to laboratory work. It concludes with a student-driven design project.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken BMEG1130 or BMEG2010 or BMEG2012 or BMEG2130 or BMEG2602 or ESTR2202 or ESTR2203 or ESTR2602.
Co-requisite: ELEG2202 or with the consent of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to

- Undertake laboratory experiments using basic techniques in electronics, chemistry, molecular biology, microbiology and electrophysiology to support the study and solution of biomedical engineering problems; and

- Apply engineering design process to the conceptual design of a biomedical engineering device; and

- Document through a written report and an oral presentation the results of an engineering design project performed as part of a team of student engineers; and

- Exhibit good safety and teamwork skills and serve as effective members of multidisciplinary project teams; and

- Understand the fundamentals and daily operation of various medical instruments from the perspectives of end-users, (doctors, technicians, nurses) and recipients (patients) through observation and work shadowing; and

- Appreciate the role of biomedical engineers in hospitals, the importance of disinfection and aseptic techniques, experience the daily operation, information flow and logistics in the running of a hospital; and

- Relate theory and engineering knowledge to practicing in a real-world setting

This course meets the Course Learning Outcomes to the BEng (BME) Programme Outcomes 1 – 8.

courses.description: This course covers biostatics, biodynamics, and biosolid mechanics and their applications to the human musculoskeletal systems and the clinical practice of orthopaedics. Topics include: force and moment vectors, equations of equilibrium, moments of inertia, kinematics of particles, Newton's second law, kinematics of rigid bodies, dynamics of rigid bodies, stress-strain relations, linear elasticity, loading and deformation, shear forces and bending moments, multi-body kinematics and application to skeletal system. Clinical scenarios will be presented with open-ended questions concerning musculoskeletal injury mechanisms associated with musculoskeletal biology (aging, gender, diseases, adverse effects of treatments) and external forces (sports and traffic accidents), basic principles for designing medical devices and implants for prevention and treatment of musculoskeletal injuries.Relevant laboratory sessions on musculoskeletal force analysis and human movement studies will be synergized with the corresponding lectures to enhance learning. Students are expected to have prior knowledge on the basic principles of Newtonian mechanics at secondary school level.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESTR2204 or MAEG2020.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course covers biostatics, biodynamics, and biosolid mechanics and their applications to the human musculoskeletal systems and the clinical practice of orthopaedics. Topics include: force and moment vectors, equations of equilibrium, moments of inertia, kinematics of particles, Newton's second law, kinematics of rigid bodies, dynamics of rigid bodies, stress-strain relations, linear elasticity, loading and deformation, shear forces and bending moments, multi-body kinematics and application to skeletal system. Clinical scenarios will be presented with open-ended questions concerning musculoskeletal injury mechanisms associated with musculoskeletal biology (aging, gender, diseases, adverse effects of treatments) and external forces (sports and traffic accidents), basic principles for designing medical devices and implants for prevention and treatment of musculoskeletal injuries.

Relevant laboratory sessions on musculoskeletal force analysis and human movement studies will be synergized with the corresponding lectures to enhance learning. Students are expected to have prior knowledge on the basic principles of Newtonian mechanics at secondary school level.

More details will be provided when available.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
We welcome students' comments and feedback on the course. There are four major channels for collecting students' feedback.

1. Tutorial: Tutorial is held every week, in which students can pass their feedback and problem about the course to the teaching assistants.

2. Informal online contact: Students can write their comments via email or newsgroup. Teaching assistants will follow up with the comments or pass the information to the course instructor if necessary.

3. Individual consulting: Students are welcome to visit the course instructor during office hours. They can exchange opinions to make the course better suits the students' needs.

4. Faculty course questionnaire: At the end of the course, students are required to provide feedback on different aspects related to teaching and learning of the course through a formal evaluation questionnaire.

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Ethical Practice in Bionic Human
courses.description: This course exposes students to a range of state-of-the-art developments in biomedical engineering. It invites students to discuss the long-term societal impacts and ethical implications of these technological advances, particularly in the use of bioengineering for human enhancements beyond therapy. The course starts by illustrating some amazing designs in our human body and yet how vulnerable we are in terms of diseases and ageing. Examples will be given on how modern biomedical engineering helps us face our human conditions and beyond, including musculoskeletal prosthetics, neural engineering, reproductive technology, stem cells and regenerative medicine, genome editing and DNA engineering, social humanoid robotics and artificial intelligence, etc. The course features related sci-fi movies and YouTube materials on bionic humans. The course wraps up with some social, ethical, and philosophical reflections on the above issues and on the future of being human, raising questions concerning the perennial human quest for transcendence.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken BMEG1217 or UGEB1217
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to (a) articulate the principles of bioethics, especially in the context of bioengineering; (b) discuss the pertinent ethical, societal and philosophical issues associated with the use of bioengineering, covering both the pros and cons of the issues; and (c) articulate the presuppositions behind their own positions regarding the above issues.

The course wraps up with some social, ethical, and philosophical reflections on the above issues and on the future of being human, raising questions concerning the perennial human quest for transcendence.

As this is a foundation course for all students, students' comments and feedback are considered an extremely important element. There are many different channels to collect the students' feedback. Formal channels include:

Course newsgroup

Students can post messages freely on the course newsgroup. The lecturer and tutors read the messages frequently.

Mid-term course evaluation

A questionnaire survey is conducted at the middle of the term to collect students' feedback.

End-of-term course evaluation

A comprehensive questionnaire survey is conducted at the end of the term to collect students' feedback. Other informal channels include email communication and individual consultation.

courses.description: This required course covers basic circuit theories that are needed for understanding the operation, as well as design of many biomedical devices. It also provides a theoretical and mathematical foundation for analyzing and processing electrical signals. Students will learn the parametric concepts commonly used for the representation, analysis and transformation of continuous-time and discrete-time signals, and the principles of processing time-varying signals in linear systems. This course emphasizes on using mathematical methods to analyze and to solve engineering problems.Specific topics of this course are: basic circuit laws and theorems, mesh and nodal analysis, superposition and source transformation; analysis of operational amplifier circuits and their biomedical applications; concept of phasor and impedance; AC analysis, introduction to transient analysis; inductors and transformers for biomedical devices; Basics of biomedical signals; continuous-time and discrete-time signals and systems; Fourier series and Fourier transform for analysis of signals and systems; convolutions/filters; sampling.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ELEG2202 or ENGG2030 or ESTR2206 or ESTR2601.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course students will have the ability to:
- State terminologies and concepts which are important in the field of circuit analysis and design.
- Apply circuit laws to analyze a linear circuit that contains resistors, capacitors, inductors, dependent and independent sources.
- Apply calculus and linear algebra in circuit analysis- Be able to simplify circuits for analysis using circuit theorems and transforms.
- Apply complex numbers and Laplace transform in AC circuit analysis
- Carry out circuit experiments independently and appreciate the importance of connecting theories to the real world through experiments
- Analyze experimental results critically
- Understand the physical meanings of signals, and how they are mathematically represented and processed.
- Understand the concept of frequency, and the frequency domain analysis of signals.
- Understand the sampling theorem and its physical implications.
- Understand how to use the Fourier transform, filtering and convolution processes.
courses.course_syllabus: This course covers basic circuit laws and theorems, mesh and nodal analysis, superposition and source transformation; analysis of operational amplifier circuits and their biomedical applications; concept of phasor and impedance; AC analysis; introduction to transient analysis; inductors and transformers for biomedical devices; basics of biomedical signals; continuous-time and discrete-time signals and systems; Fourier series and Fourier transform for analysis of signals and systems; convolutions/filters; biosignal sampling.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
As this is a foundation course for all students in electronic engineering, students' comments and feedback are considered an extremely important element. There are many different channels to collect the students' feedback. Formal channels include:

Tutorial
Tutorialsare conducted in a highly interactive way. Students can speak directly to the tutors if they have any comments and suggestion on the course content and teaching.

Course newsgroup
Students can post messages freely on the course newsgroup. The lecturer and tutors readthe messages frequently.

Mid-termcourse evaluation
A questionnaire survey is conducted at the middle of the term to collect students' feedback.

End-of-term course evaluation
A comprehensive questionnaire survey is conducted at the end of the term to collect students' feedback.
Other informal channels include email communication and individual consultation.

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Complex Analysis and Differential Equations
courses.description: This course covers complex analysis and differential equations. Topics of complex analysis include analytic functions, Cauchy Riemann, complex integration, Cauchy principal value, elementary complex valued functions, exponential functions, Euler's formula, trigonometric and hyperbolic functions, logarithm and general powers, power series, Taylor series and convergence tests. Topics of differential equations include classification of differential equations, 1st order ordinary differential equations, 2nd order ordinary differential equations, and partial differential equations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENGG2420 or 2460 or ESTR2000 or 2010
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the basic elements of complex analysis
2. obtain competence to solve mathematical problems relevant to engineering with the 1st and 2nd order ordinary differential equations and partial differential equations
3. model engineering problems

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Hospital Experience and Engineering Practicum
courses.description: This course aims to enrich student experience in hospital environment and appreciation of laboratory skills, engineering and electrical safety and ethical issues. Students will have the opportunity to visit various hospital facilities and laboratories. This course includes professional workshops on laboratory skills and appreciation of ethical issues relevant to the biomedical engineering discipline.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ENGG2602.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
- Hand-on skills of engineering practice; and
- Understand the fundamentals and daily operation of various medical instruments from the perspectives of end-users, (doctors, technicians, nurses and recipients (patients) through observation and work shadowing; and
- Appreciate the role of biomedical engineers in hospitals, the importance of disinfection and aseptic techniques, experience the daily operation, information flow and logistics in the running of a hospital; and
- Relate theory and engineering knowledge to practicing in a real-world setting; and
- Appreciate the critical importance of safety and ethical issues relevant to the biomedical engineering discipline.

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Medical Instrumentation and Design
courses.description: In view of the prevalence of the aging population and accompanying chronic illnesses, demands for medical instrumentation and design have been escalating worldwide. This course aims at enabling students to master design-thinking skills and by applying it to the broad medical fields. Laboratory sessions will be arranged to train students in developing prototypes and enrich their understanding of the fundamental design concepts covered in lectures.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ELEG3101 or BMEG3111 or ESTR3210 or ESTR3601 or ESTR3603.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course covers the fundamental concepts of design of medical instrumentation and sensors; origins and measurements of bioelectric and ultrasonic signals; electrical safety and hazard; and application examples including electrocardiography (ECG) measurements, pulse oximetry, biosensors cochlear implant devices, functional electric stimulators and drug delivery systems, etc.
Students have to form groups to produce a medical device prototype that fulfills a list of design goals. Upon completing this course, students should have acquired basic engineering design skills and practical problem-solving skills that are directly transferable to further design work in their future careers.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Feedback from students can be made via the following channels:
1. Tutorials
Weekly tutorials are provided for students to express their feedback and problems about the course and the design project to the teaching assistants.

2. Informal online contact
Students can show their comments via email or newsgroup. Teaching assistants will follow up with the comments or pass the information to the course instructor if necessary.

3. Individual consulting
Students can make appointments with the course instructor and teaching assistants to exchange opinions for improving the quality of course.

4. Faculty course questionnaire
At the end of the course, students are required to fill in the questionnaire to provide feedback on different aspects, including comments on the teaching and learning of the course.
courses.required_readings: Relevant reading list will be provided by course teachers.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Medical Instrumentation, 4th Edition, Ed. by John Webster.
2. Biodesign: The Process of Innovating Medical Technologies by Zenios, Makower and Yock.
3. Biomedical Transducers and Instruments by Togawa, Tamura, and Oberg.
4. Introduction to Biomedical Equipment Technology, 3rd Edition, by Carr and Brown.

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Bioinformatics
courses.description: This course introduces the basic concepts in bioinformatics. On the theoretical side, students are expected to learn the relevant knowledge in computer science, biology and mathematics from lectures and tutorials. On the practical side, they are given assignments and tutorials to get hands-on experience in locating, studying and using developed tools to apply the learned concepts in performing standard analytical tasks on biomedical data. Topics to be covered include: introduction to bioinformatics, reviews of molecular biology and genetics, biomedical data types and databases, sequence alignment and searching methods, mutation models and molecular phylogenetics, molecular structures, basics of human genetics and genetic diseases, clinical bioinformatics for genetic diseases diagnosis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ELEG4120 or CSCI3220 or ESTR3110.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to
- Tell the main ideas in bioinformatics, and its roles in biomedical engineering; and
- Apply learned algorithms and skills to carry out standard analytical tasks, such as sequence alignment and phylogenetic tree reconstruction; and
- Develop innovative engineering tools and software modules for bioinformatics analysis
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces the basic concepts in bioinformatics. On the theoretical side, students are expected to learn the relevant knowledge in computer science, biology and mathematics from lectures and tutorials. On the practical side, they are given assignments and tutorials to get hands-on experience in locating, studying and using developed tools to apply the learned concepts in performing standard analytical tasks on biomedical data. Topics to be covered include: introduction to bioinformatics, reviews of molecular biology and genetics, biomedical data types and databases, sequence alignment and searching methods, mutation models and molecular phylogenetics, molecular structures, basics of human genetics and genetic diseases, clinical bioinformatics for genetic diseases diagnosis.
More details will be provided when available.
courses.feedback_evaluation: We welcome feedbacks and comments on the course from the students. There are many channels setup for collecting feedbacks. Students are encouraged to talk to the teachers before and after lectures, during lecture breaks, or during designated consultation hours. They can talk to the teaching assistants during tutorials. They can contact the teachers and teaching assistants by email or using the online discussion forum. They can make anonymous suggestions by filling in the informal midterm evaluation questionnaire to be conducted in the middle of the term. They can also provide feedbacks using the official course evaluation questionnaire conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Relevant reading list will be provided by course teachers.
courses.recommended_readings:
There are no official text books for this course

There are no official text books for this course. Here are some recommended reference books:

- Fundamental Concepts of Bioinformatics, by Dan E. Krane and Michael L. Raymer, Benjamin Cummings/Pearson Education, 2003, ISBN: 0-8053-4633-3.

- Algorithms in Bioinformatics: A Practical Introduction, by Wing-Kin Sung, Chapman & Hall, 2009, ISBN: 978-1420070330.

- Clinical Bioinformatics, editor(s): Ronald J.A. Trent, series: Methods in Molecular Medicine Volume No.: 141, ISBN: 978-1-58829-791-4.

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Big Data in HealthCare
courses.description: This course will cover clinical ontologies and standards, clinical databases, electronic health record systems, event reporting systems, real-time monitoring systems, acquisition and mining of data from portable medical devices, heterogeneous data integration, topic models for free-text medical records, trend analysis and medical recommendation systems. Students form teams from different disciplines and each team would tackle a particular healthcare big data repository to go through the process of data analytics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, students should be able:

1. To understand and make use of the clinical record systems for processing, storing, retrieving and analyzing the data
2. To apply AI and Machine Learning in clinical applications in System Level
3. To understand the design principles behind those systems and algorithms
4. To design their own systems with specifically targeted applications
5. To develop the skills of turning concepts and designs into practices and solve complex engineering problems
6. To understand how healthcare big data can provide positive societal impacts and values
7. To have an increased awareness and responsibility of promoting healthcare big data
courses.course_syllabus: This course will cover clinical ontologies and standards, clinical databases, electronic health record systems, event reporting systems, real-time monitoring systems, acquisition and mining of data from portable medical devices, heterogeneous data integration, topic models for free-text medical records, trend analysis, and medical recommendation systems.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course will be evaluated annually with students’ feedback and evaluate with the impacts from the project AI Systems in Healthcare sector. The course will be continuously improved in the arrangement and course content based on the collected feedback.

courses.recommended_readings: Relevant reading list will be provided by course teachers.

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Data Analytics for Personalized Genomics and Precision Medicine
courses.description: This course will cover high-throughput experimental methods, standard data processing pipelines, sequence alignment and mapping, foundational concepts of data analytics, data exploration and visualization, clustering and classification, dimension reduction, and their applications in personalized genomics and precision medicine. For personalized genomics, we will also cover the integration of heterogeneous sequencing and non-sequencing data, single-cell data analysis, multi-omics analysis methods, and cancer genomics. For precision medicine, we will cover protein-RNA interactions, biological graph analysis, and gentle introduction to biomedical imaging and electronic health records.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESTR3605.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, students should be able:

1. Present the different kinds of data in personalized genomics and precision medicine.

2. Describe the basic concepts, procedure, and intuition of data analytics, such as data cleaning, clustering, classification, dimension reduction.

3. Apply the data analytical techniques to analyze the personalized genomics and precision medicine data, such as cell genomics, single cell genomics, and bio-images.

4. Analyze the performance of the machine learning method and understand their limitations.

5. Enhance problem-solving ability, communication and presentation skills by doing course project.
courses.course_syllabus: This course will cover high-throughput experimental methods, standard data processing pipelines, sequence alignment and mapping, foundational concepts of data analytics, data exploration and visualization, clustering and classification, dimension reduction, and their applications in personalized genomics and precision medicine. For personalized genomics, we will also cover the integration of heterogeneous sequencing and non-sequencing data, single-cell data analysis, multi-omics analysis methods, and cancer genomics. For precision medicine, we will cover protein-RNA interactions, biological graph analysis, and gentle introduction to biomedical imaging and electronic health records.

courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students are expected to:
1. Obtain knowledge of basic cell biology, molecular biology and biomedical engineering.
2. Demonstrate an ability to design and conduct molecular and cellular engineering experiments, as well as to analyze and interpret the data.
3. Demonstrate an ability to identify, formulate, and solve problems in molecular and cellular engineering experiments.
4. Demonstrate an ability to critically evaluate research and professional literature, and understand the principles and practice of conducting research in clinical and industrial environments related to molecular and cellular engineering.

courses.description: This course introduces the fundamental knowledge in fluid mechanics, including nature of fluids, integral and differential equations of fluid flows, conservation of mass, momentum and energy, basic mass transfer, inviscid flow, viscous-dominated flows, navier-stokes equation, dimensional analysis, internal and external flows and reynolds number. It covers micro-fluidic devices and biological applications. It also describes fluids in human body and blood flow, including blood velocity, blood vessel geometry and respiratory mechanics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MAEG3030 or ESTR3212.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should have acquired the ability to:

Upon completion of this course, students should have acquired the ability to:

- Understand the fundamental concepts of fluid mechanics.

- Apply the principle of conservation of mass, momentum to perform various flow analysis

- Understand the state-of-the-art microfluidic devices and their applications in biology

- Perform dimensional analysis for complex flow system and design proper experiments

* *-**Perform basic quantitative analysis on simple biological flow system
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces the fundamental knowledge in fluid mechanics, including nature of fluids, integral and differential equations of fluid flows, conservation of mass, momentum and energy, basic mass transfer, inviscid flow, viscous-dominated flows, navier-stokes equation, dimensional analysis, internal and external flows and reynolds number. It covers micro-fluidic devices and biological applications. It also describes fluids in human body and blood flow, including blood velocity, blood vessel geometry and respiratory mechanics.

More details will be provided when available.

courses.description: This course covers the fundamentals of biomedical imaging: the physiology and physics that are involved in the imaging process (waves, spins, resonance, radioactive decay), the mathematics that are needed to modelize the image formation (linear algebra, multidimensional calculus, 2D Fourier transform, Radon transform, probabilities), the signal and image processing techniques that help analyse digital images (2D filtering, discrete 2D Fourier transform, interpolation, contrast, quality), and the hardware used for acquiring these images (X-ray tubes, detectors, magnets, coils, gamma cameras, transductors). A particular emphasis will be laid on four imaging modalities: X-ray radiography, Computed Tomography (CT), Emission Computed Tomography (scintigraphy, SPECT and PET), Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and Ultrasound Imaging.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: BMEG2300 or ENGG2030 or with the consent of the instructor.
courses.component:
Exercise
Laboratory
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should have acquired the ability to
1. Understand common techniques for generating and processing biomedical images.
2. Understand the physical principles, usages and limitations of each imaging modality.
3. Enumerate which physical or physiological properties can be measured with each modality.
4. Recognize the different imaging systems and their basic parts.
5. Understand the importance of using imaging as a tool for the study in biomedical engineering.
6. Obtain useful biomedical and health information from various types of biomedical images.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course teaches the fundamentals of biomedical imaging: the physiology and physics that are involved in the imaging process (waves, spins, resonance, radioactive decay), the mathematics that are needed to modelize the image formation (linear algebra, multidimensional calculus, 2D Fourier transform, Radon transform, probabilities), the signal and image processing techniques that help analyse digital images (2D filtering, discrete 2D Fourier transform, interpolation, contrast, quality), and the hardware used for acquiring these images (X-ray tubes, detectors, magnets, coils, gamma cameras, transductors). A particular emphasis will be laid on four imaging modalities: X-ray radiography, Computed Tomography (CT), Emission Computed Tomography (scintigraphy, SPECT and PET), Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and Ultrasound Imaging.

More information will be provided when available.

2. Tutorial: Tutorial is held every week, in which students can pass their feedback and problem about the course to the teaching assistants, who forward to the course instructor.
3. Informal online contact
Students write their comments via email or news forums on Moodle. The course instructor and the teaching assistants follow up with the comments.

Students are welcome to visit the course instructor during office hours, or by appointment. They can exchange opinions to make the course better suits the students' needs.

courses.description: This course discusses the introduction of neuroengineering: the past, the current status and the future. The topics cover Neural system and neuron activity; Neural modeling and computation; Neural information processing, Neuromuscular systems and Electromyography (EMG); Brain-computer interface (BCI) and neuroprosthesis: functional electrical stimulation, retina and cochlea; Electric and magnetic field of human brain (EEG and MEG), transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS); Transcranial direct-current stimulation (tDCS); biopotential electrode and amplifier; Mechanisms underlying neurological disorders (stroke, Parkinson's disease Alzheimer’s Disease or epilepsy); optogenetic technology, principles and applications of neuroimaging such as functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Selected state-of-the-art topics in a highly interdisciplinary field that combines neuroscience, electrophysiology, neural activity imaging, optics and engineering technologies. Other selected topics of recent research interests.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESTR3602.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Understand the fundamentals and characteristics of neural system and neuron activities
* Understand the causes, mechanism and therapy of various neurological disorders
* Understand the basics of neural computation and brain computer interface
* Understand the fundamental approaches of neural information processing
* Understand fundamental theory of neuroscience, EEG, MEG, TMS, tDCS, fMRI, optogenetic technology
* Know the design process of neuroengineering devices
courses.course_syllabus:
This course discusses the introduction of neuroengineering: the past, the current status and the future. The topics cover Neural system and neuron activity; Neural modeling and computation; Neural information processing, Neuromuscular systems and Electromyography (EMG); Brain-computer interface (BCI) and neuroprosthesis: functional electrical stimulation, retina and cochlea; Electric and magnetic field of human brain (EEG and MEG), transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS); Transcranial direct-current stimulation (tDCS); biopotential electrode and amplifier; Mechanisms underlying neurological disorders (stroke, Parkinson's disease or epilepsy); optogenetic technology, principles and applications of neuroimaging such as functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Selected state-of-the-art topics in a highly interdisciplinary field that combines neuroscience, electrophysiology, neural activity imaging, optics and engineering technologies. Other selected topics of recent research interests.

A design project of an EEG device to enhance students engineering design skills and problem solving skills. A design project of an EEG device aims at enabling students to master design-thinking and, by following a problem-based group approach. Students have to form groups to produce a medical device prototype that fulfills a list of design goals. Upon completing this course, students should have acquired basic engineering design skills and practical problem-solving skills that are directly transferable to further design work in their future careers.

courses.description: Many successful designs and startups begin in university years. This course involves projects that are led by students and aims at accelerating them to prepare for engineering medical innovation in which teams of students design and develop clinically-driven and client-centered engineering innovations for the future of medicine & healthcare. This course aims at enabling students to master design-thinking and, by following a problem-based group approach, apply it to the broad medical fields. Students have to form groups of size 2 to 4 to develop from an idea to become viable medical device in the market. In the process, students work on ideas, market research, prototyping, developing operation strategies, conducting pilot tests, designing market survey and preparing business proposal to sell their product or ideas. Upon completing this course, students should have acquired engineering design skills and entrepreneurship skills that are directly transferable to further innovation work.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Feedback from students can be made via the following channels:
1. Project meeting
Weekly project meetings are provided for students to express their feedback and problems about the course and the design project to the teaching assistants and mentors.

2. Informal online contact
Students can show their comments via email or newsgroup. Teaching assistants will follow up with the comments or pass the information to the course instructor if necessary.

3. Individual consulting
Students can make appointments with the course instructor and teaching assistants to exchange opinions for improving the quality of course.

4. Faculty course questionnaire
At the end of the course, students are required to fill in the questionnaire to provide feedback on different aspects, including comments on the teaching and learning of the course.
courses.required_readings: Relevant reading list will be provided by course teachers.

3. Medical Instrumentation, 4th Edition, Ed. by John Webster.
4. Introduction to Biomedical Equipment Technology, 3rd Edition, by Carr and Brown.

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Cross-Cultural Biomedical Collaboration for Global Health Challenges
courses.description: In the context of a growing global emphasis on big health initiatives and preventive care, the demand for innovative medical technologies and health solutions continues to rise. This course is designed to equip students from China, Hong Kong, and the UK with design-thinking skills that they will apply to the broad field of big health. Through global collaboration, students will work in international teams, drawing on diverse perspectives and expertise from biomedical and electronic engineering disciplines. Laboratory sessions and project-based modules will enable students to develop prototypes that address global health challenges.By engaging in cross-border teamwork, students will not only deepen their understanding of key design concepts and embedded systems, such as microcontroller skills but also gain invaluable experience in collaborating across different cultural and academic environments. This global exposure will enrich their training and better prepare them for international careers in health technology and innovation, providing a solid foundation to tackle the global challenges in preventive care, wellness, and healthcare system transformation.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course covers the fundamental concepts of engineering design and big health and its application in global healthcare innovation, with a strong emphasis on international collaboration. Students from China, Hong Kong, and the UK will work in interdisciplinary teams, leveraging their diverse backgrounds to design and develop health technologies focused on preventive care, wellness, and managing the aging population. The course addresses the origins and measurements of vital physiological signals, biosensing device integration, and the design of medical instrumentation for health monitoring. Upon completing this course, students will have developed essential collaboration and problem-solving skills, with direct applicability to global health challenges. These skills will be valuable for future careers in health technology and biomedical engineering, preparing students to lead innovation in international healthcare environments.

Laboratory sessions and design project modules will be structured around international teamwork, enabling students to collaborate across borders and bring unique perspectives from their regions. Students will develop prototypes, improve their design-thinking, and enhance their modeling and coding skills (e.g., Python, SolidWorks, programming). By working together with peers from different countries, students will not only enrich their academic experience but also expand their global networks, positioning them for successful careers in a rapidly evolving healthcare landscape.

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Global Medical Device Regulatory Affairs
courses.description: This course provides an overview on global medical device regulation. Regulatory affairs refer to how to get a medical product registered in different countries’ health authorities. A registered product would demand a lot of technical documentation to prove its efficacy, safety, and quality. To successfully and smoothly register a product, knowledge and skills are required to deal with various key stakeholders in governments, testing centers, hospitals, and medical doctors. The course is characterized by its unique international focus. In addition to learning Hong Kong, Chinese Mainland and Asia regulatory affairs, students would learn European and US medical device regulatory system to facilitate the medical device to be marketed around the world.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken BMEG5850 or ESTR4601.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Able to describe how to meet standards and regulatory requirements of medical devices in US, Europe and Asia.
• Able to handle regulatory tasks included classification, risk management and product registration.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course provides an overview on global medical device regulation. Regulatory affairs refer to how to get a medical product registered in different countries’ health authorities. A registered product would demand a lot of technical documentation to prove its efficacy, safety, and quality. To successfully and smoothly register a product, knowledge and skills are required to deal with various key stakeholders in governments, testing centers, hospitals, and medical doctors. The course is characterized by its unique international focus. In addition to learning Hong Kong, Chinese Mainland and Asia regulatory affairs, students would learn European and US medical device regulatory system to facilitate the medical device to be marketed around the world.
This course aims to give both factual and practical experiences on what is regulatory requirement and how to handle future regulatory tasks, included classification, risk management, product registration and commercial materials review.
Students would form teams from different disciplines and each team would tackle a particular medical device of their choices to go through the processes of the regulatory requirements. The project ideas will be put into the reality and through public channels.

4. Handbook of medical device regulatory affairs in Asia, Jack Wong and Raymond Tong, Pan Stanford Publishing, 2013
5. Biodesign: The Process of Innovating New Medical Technologies, Stefanos A Zenios; Josh Makower; Paul G Yock , Cambridge University Press, 2010

courses.description: This course provides knowledge and technical background on the current available AI and imaging technologies developed for biomedical engineering applications. The AI part focus on introducing recent cutting-edge advances in computer vision, deep learning, neural networks, robotics, and machine intelligence and their applications in clinical diagnostics, medical operations, tissue engineering, and regenerative medicine. The imaging part emphasis lies on introducing advanced biomedical imaging modalities, including QCT, pQCT, microCT for animals and human, nano-CT, multimodal MRI, ultrasound, and other advanced imaging modalities. It also covers applications of biomedical imaging in diagnosis, prevention and treatment of aging related disorders of cardiovascular, neurodegeneration and other relevant living systems. Selected topics relating to use the above AI and imaging technologies for evaluation of scaffold biomaterials, repair of musculoskeletal tissues, diagnostics and evaluation of neurodegeneration diseases and cancers, and so on will be covered.

courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
1. Understand the basic concepts of advanced AI technologies and their applications in biomedical engineering.
2. Understand the fundamental concepts and categories of biomedical imaging technologies.
3. Acquire knowledge and practical skills in implementation AI to biomedical engineering and biomedical imaging
4. Understand the basic imaging approaches for relevant biomedical applications (e.g., regenerative medicine and musculoskeletal applications).
5. Acquire basic operation skills of mainstream imaging devices and data acquisition methods.

courses.description: BioMEMS is the application of MEMS (Microelectromechanical Systems) technology in the fields of biomedical and health sciences. Due to their small size (1 μm ~ 1 mm), BioMEMS have the advantages of low weight, low cost, quick response, high throughput, high efficiency, requiring much less sample/reagent, and easy system integration. BioMEMS has found broad applications in disease diagnosis, prevention, and treatment. Various bioMEMS products have been developed, such as microfluidic devices, neural interface devices, μTAS (micro Total Analysis Systems), Lab-on-a-Chip, DNA Chips, micro drug delivery system, microsurgical tools, biosensors. This course covers the introduction of BioMEMS, techniques used in constructing the devices, patterning biomolecules, biomedical problems that can be addressed by the BioMEMS technology, as well as the associated engineering challenges.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESTR4203.
courses.component:
Discussion
Laboratory
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
courses.course_syllabus:
This course provides the introduction to bioMEMS, scaling Law and basic MEMS fabrication technologies including UV lithography, soft lithography, micromolding, nanoimprinting, micropatterning of substrates and cells, microfluidic devices and components for bio-MEMS. It also covers micropumps, micromixers, droplet microfluidics, BioMEMS applications for molecular biology, cell biology and tissue engineering.

More details will be provided when available.

courses.description: This course consists of two parts. The first half covers basic concepts in nanotechnology (e.g., length scales (less than 100 nm) effect on properties of materials and devices), and introduces techniques and tools for fabricating nanostructured and bioengineered materials: quantum dots, DNA, self-assembly and templating, surface patterning, and functionalization. The second half introduces three key applications of nanotechnology in biomedical research (i.e., diagnostics, in vivo imaging, and targeted drug delivery), and briefly discusses the process of translating laboratory discoveries to therapies applicable in clinical trials.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken BMEG5760 or ESTR4202.
courses.course_syllabus: This course consists of two parts. The second half introduces three key applications of nanotechnology in biomedical research (i.e., diagnostics, in vivo imaging, and targeted drug delivery), and briefly discusses the process of translating laboratory discoveries to therapies applicable in clinical trials.

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Biomolecular Engineering
courses.description: This course consists of two parts. The first half covers basic concepts in biomolecular engineering, including structure and properties of biomolecules (e.g., nucleic acid, protein, lipid, and sugar), the central dogma of molecular biology, and regulation of gene expression. Building on the theoretical framework from the first half, the second half introduces experimental tools involved in biomolecular engineering research, including synthesis and characterization of DNA and protein, gene recombination, and basic genomics. Set at the advanced undergraduate level, the course focuses on developing students’ ability to analyze research data and critique the scientific literature.

courses.description: This course introduces the application of the principles of biology and engineering to the development of viable substitutes which restore, maintain, or improve the function of musculoskeletal tissues. Topics include musculoskeletal tissues: tissue engineering of tendon/ligament, cartilage and bone. It focuses on the understanding the interactions between extracellular matrices and cells, mechanobiological responses of cells/tissues. It also discusses musculoskeletal biomaterials including the development of bioactive, biomimetic advanced biological materials for replacement of aged and diseased musculoskeletal tissues.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Prerequisite: BMEG3430 or with the consent of the instructor.
Not for students who have taken ESTR4214.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should have achieved the following outcomes:
1. Understand the fundamentals and characteristics of tissue and musculoskeletal engineering.
2. Understand the development and modeling of different biomaterials.
3. Understand the musculoskeletal tissues related to tendon/ligament, cartilage, bone, and the interaction between extracellular matrix and cells.
4. Understand and measure mechanobiological responses of cells/tissues.
5. Appreciate the use of bioactive, biomimetic advanced biological materials for replacement of aged and diseased musculoskeletal tissues.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces the application of the principles of biology and engineering to the development of viable substitutes which restore, maintain, or improve the function of musculoskeletal tissues. Topics include musculoskeletal tissues: tissue engineering of tendon/ligament, cartilage and bone. It focuses on the understanding the interactions between extracellular matrices and cells, mechanobiological responses of cells/tissues. It also discusses musculoskeletal biomaterials including the development of bioactive, biomimetic advanced biological materials for replacement of aged and diseased musculoskeletal tissues.

courses.description: This course introduces the origins of physiological signals, the mechanisms of bioelectrical, biochemical, biophysical, and biophotonic sensors. It covers the principles of wearable medical devices for homecare and mobile health care system. Students will learn features of body sensor networks (BSN), security issues for BSN, multi-sensor data fusion for BSN, wearable and implantable sensor integration, wearable devices and sensors for monitoring, diagnosis, therapy, spots, etc. and applications of medical devices, biosensors, and BSN.

Professor WANG Dongan

Professor GAO Zhaoli, 
Professor WANG Dongan

Professor GAO Zhaoli, 
Professor WANG Dongan

courses.description: This course covers the essential elements of bioelectronics and nanotechnology specific to biomedical engineering. The first part of this course (Bioelectronics) includes overview of bioelectronics, functional materials for bioelectronics, biomolecule-based transistors, electrochemical biosensors, device fabrication and characterisation, lab-on-a-chip, wearable devices, and implantable bioelectronics and bionics.The second part of this course (Nanotechnology) includes introduction to nanotechnology, nanolithography, solution-based synthesis of nano-materials, characterisation techniques, scanning probe-based biomanipulation, soft-lithography for DNA, proteins and cells, self-assembly of peptides and proteins, nanoscale drug delivery systems, and bio-nano-informatics fusion.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or
For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science; or
For students in MPhil-PhD Biomedical Engineering
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to:
- Understand the essential elements of bioelectronics and nanotechnology in the context that it is the fusion between biotechnology and nanotechnology;
- Appreciate the impact of bioelectronics and nanotechnology in the field of biomedical engineering; and
- Understand the key processing technologies involved in the fabrication of practical devices based on bioelectronics concepts and nanotechnology.

courses.description: This course aims to provide students from different science & engineering backgrounds opportunities to learn how to fabricate simple medical materials and devices, how to collect data on human subjects and other biological samples, and how to analyze the results to address various health-related issues. The course starts with a series of lectures on the principles underpinning each of the planned laboratory modules. Students will then form teams to conduct a number of hand-on laboratory modules in different areas of biomedical engineering to achieve the course aims and learning outcomes. Examples of laboratory modules include fabrication of basic biomedical device for biosignal acquisition, advanced electrophysiological techniques, fabrication of biomaterials for drug deliveries, PCR and gel electrophoresis, confocal fluorescence microscopy, functional MRI data processing, biomedical imaging for musculoskeletal applications, measurement of interfacial pressure at body support surfaces, electromyography & exoskeleton hand robot, etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes:

1. Able to demonstrate the basic attitudes and skills needed to conduct BME measurements on human subjects and on other biological specimens;
2. Able to articulate the fundamental principles underpinning those BME measurements; and

3. Able to perform quantitative analysis of the data collected to address related biomedical issues.

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Medical Device Regulatory Affairs and Intellectual Property
courses.description: This course provides an overview on medical device regulation and intellectual property. Regulatory affairs is how to get a medical product registered in different countries’ health authorities. A registered product would demand a lot of technical documentation to prove its efficacy, safety, and quality. To successfully and smoothly register a product, knowledge and skills are required to deal with various key stakeholders in governments, testing centers, hospitals, and medical doctors. Intellectual Property, such as patent, is to protect the invention and to support licensing their rights to manufacturers in the medical device industry.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering; or
For students in MSc Biochemistry & Biomedical Science; or
For students in MPhil-PhD Biomedical Engineering;Not for students who have taken BMEG4010
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes:
1. Able to describe how to meet standards and regulatory requirements of medical devices in US, Europe and Asia;
2. Able to demonstrate an understanding of the practical knowledge about intellectual property, such as patent; and
3. Able to describe how to apply and file a patent application, and issues related to patent defence.

courses.description: This course introduces the concepts of tele-medicine, electronic-medicine (E-health), and mobile-health (M-health). It covers basic techniques in tele-medicine and M-health, namely communication systems and networks, medical devices, E-medical records, information security and confidentiality, medical data coding and compression, functions of picture archiving and communication systems (PACS) and health information systems (HIS). Applications of E-health technologies, which include tele-surgery, tele-geriatrics, tele-monitoring and M-health etc, will be covered.

1. Able to acquire fundamental knowledge and latest developments on tele-medicine, e-medicine, and mobile-health;
2. Able to know the fundamentals and current research directions on medical data coding and compression methods; and
3. Able to know the basic structure and latest technology of PACS and HIS.

courses.subject: BMEG
courses.title: Golden Age Opportunities and Sustainable Smart Ageing

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803

courses.description: This course is designed to prepare students for successful careers in biomedical engineering and healthcare sectors, with a specific focus on golden age opportunities and healthy ageing/longevity. It aims to offer a comprehensive exploration of the multifaceted aspects of ageing, combining theoretical knowledge with practical applications. A key component of the course will be the sustainability policy model, emphasizing the importance of technological advancements to ensure that an ageing society receives high-quality healthcare services at affordable costs. Over the span of 13 weeks, students will begin with the fundamentals of ageing bioengineering and progress through critical topics such as the investment landscape, business development, and regulatory frameworks in the ageing industry. The curriculum includes advanced subjects like bioinformatics in longevity research, deep learning algorithms for ageing modulation, and computational strategies for senolytics discovery. Guest speakers from the venture capital and longevity medicine sectors will provide real-world insights, while field trips will enhance experiential learning. Ethical, social, and economic impacts of ageing technologies will be examined, culminating in advanced therapeutic approaches in geriatric care. The course will conclude with student presentations of capstone projects, allowing participants to synthesize their learning and propose innovative solutions in the field of ageing bioengineering.
